questions.question: Question 1: What is the most common cause of endogenous hyperthyroidism?
questions.explanation:
Graves' disease is the most common cause of endogenous hyperthyroidism. It is an autoimmune disorder due to the production of TSH-receptor stimulating 
immunoglobulins (TSI) which cause hyperthyroidism. It is characterized by the triad of: • Thyrotoxicosis • Infiltrative ophthalmopathy (exophthalmos) • Dermopathy (pretibial myxedema) Glycosaminoglycan deposition, lymphoid infiltrates, and fatty infiltrates are responsible for 
ophthalmopathy and dermopathy. Grossly, there is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland and a beefy deep red parenchyma. 
Histology shows tall crowded follicular cells with scalloped margins and lymphoid infiltrates. 
Laboratory features include elevations in free T3 and T4 and decreased TSH.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 32-year-old lady presents with loss of weight, tremors of the hand, and irritability for the 
past 4-5 months. Examination findings and investigations are given below. All of the 
following contribute to these eye findings except:

options.a: Lymphocytic infiltration in the retroorbital space

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with the given image showing exophthalmos is suggestive of 
Graves' ophthalmopathy. Sympathetic overactivity of Muller's muscle results in a wide, staring 
gaze and lid lag, but not exophthalmos. Exophthalmos is characterized by abnormal protrusion of the eyeball. It is due to increased 
volume of the retroorbital connective tissues and extraocular muscles because of: 1148 
Sold by @itachibot • Marked lymphocytic infiltration of the retro-orbital space • Inflammation with edema and swelling of extraocular muscles • Accumulation of hydrophilic glycosaminoglycans such as hyaluronic acid and chondroitin sulfate • Increased numbers of adipocytes (fatty infiltration)

questions.question:
Question 3: 1139 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following disorders does not lead to hyperthyroidism?
questions.explanation:
Hashimoto thyroiditis is not associated with hyperthyroidism. It is associated with 
transient thyrotoxicosis, followed by chronic hypothyroidism. Thyrotoxicosis is a hypermetabolic state caused by elevated circulating levels of free T3 and T4. 
On the other hand, hyperfunctioning of the thyroid gland itself is referred to as hyperthyroidism.

questions.question:
Question 4: What is the finding seen in the following histopathological examination of a biopsy specimen 
from a patient with an enlarged thyroid?

options.a: Dense lymphoid infiltrate with germinal centre

questions.explanation:
The given image shows follicular hyperplasia with a scalloping colloid. The clinical scenario along 
with the image is suggestive of Graves' disease. In Graves' disease, the thyroid is diffusely hyperplastic. The follicles are lined by tall columnar 
epithelial cells that project into lumina. The cells actively resorb the colloid in the center of the 
follicle which results in a scalloped appearance of the edges of the colloid. 1149 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: A 50-year-old woman presented with diffuse thyroid swelling for the past 6 months. She says 
that it has increased in size over the last 1 month. Investigations reveal elevated TSH levels. 
Histopathological examination is done, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? 1140 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical picture and image showing Hurthle cells are suggestive of Hashimoto's 
thyroiditis. In this condition, the following microscopic features are seen: • Intense lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well developed 
germinal centers • Atrophied thyroid follicles • The epithelial cells lining the follicles contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm (oncocytes) • This is called oncocytic metaplasia • These cells are called Hurthle cells 1150 
Sold by @itachibot • Ultrastructurally, these cells have numerous mitochondria Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease, characterized by the gradual destruction of the 
thyroid gland leading to thyroid failure. It is commonly seen in women between 45 to 65 years of 
age. It is caused by the presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid 
peroxidase. Morphologically, there is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland, with an intact capsule. It is 
well demarcated from the adjacent structures. Note: Oncocytes can arise in various tissues and are referred to as follows: • Hurthle cells/ Ashkenazy cells - thyroid gland • Oxyphilic cells - parotid gland • Apocrine metaplasia - breast 1151 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following findings will you not observe in a thyroid gland biopsy taken from a 
patient suffering from Hashimoto thyroiditis?
questions.explanation:
Orphan-Annie eye nuclei are a feature of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, not Hashimoto's 
thyroiditis. Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroid 
gland and gradual and progressive thyroid failure. It is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in areas of the world where iodine levels are 
sufficient. The thyroid gland is often diffusely enlarged, painless, with some degree of hypothyroidism. This 
may be preceded by transient thyrotoxicosis (Hashitoxicosis). It is associated with an increased 
risk of: • Other autoimmune conditions • Extranodal marginal zone B-cell lymphomas • Papillary carcinoma Histologically, the following findings are seen: • Intense lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well developed 
germinal centers • Atrophied thyroid follicles • The epithelial cells lining the follicles contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm • This is called oncocytic metaplasia • These cells are called Hurthle cells 1152 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 7: What is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas of the world?
questions.explanation:
Autoimmune hypothyroidism is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient 
areas of the world. The thyroid gland is typically enlarged. The circulating autoantibodies found in this disorder are: • Antimicrosomal antibodies • Antithyroid peroxidase antibodies • Antithyroglobulin antibodies Note: Wolff-Chaikoff effect refers to iodine-induced hypothyroidism.

questions.question:
Question 8: A 48-year-old woman presented with fever, malaise, and painful enlargement of the thyroid 
gland after a few days following viral fever. On investigation, thyroid antibodies were normal 
and serum T4 was slightly raised. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical condition is suggestive of subacute granulomatous thyroiditis. It is the most common cause of a painful thyroid. It is also known as painful subacute thyroiditis, 
de Quervain thyroiditis, or migratory thyroiditis (this is because the pain can shift to different 
locations in the thyroid). Option A: Subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis (postpartum thyroiditis) is typically painless. It often 
occurs after pregnancy and is characterized by lymphocytic inflammation in the thyroid. Option B: Riedel's thyroiditis is a rare disorder characterized by a painless, rapidly growing 
thyroid mass with extensive fibrosis involving the thyroid and contiguous neck structures. Option C: Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease that presents as painless enlargement 
of the thyroid associated with some degree of hypothyroidism in middle-aged women. 1153 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following statements about solitary thyroid nodule is incorrect?

options.a: They are more common in women
options.c: Solitary nodules are more likely to be malignant than are multiple nodules
options.d: Nodules in younger patients are less likely to be malignant

questions.explanation:
Nodules in younger patients are more likely to be malignant than those in older patients. The solitary thyroid nodule is a palpably discrete swelling within an otherwise apparently normal 
thyroid gland. A higher incidence is seen in areas with endemic iodine deficiency. They are more 
common in women than in men. Malignant transformation is more common in: • Solitary nodules > Multinodular goiter • Solitary nodules in males > females • Cold nodules > Hot nodules However, benign neoplasms are more common than thyroid carcinomas by a ratio of nearly 10:1.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is the most common thyroid cancer?
questions.explanation:
The most common thyroid cancer is papillary carcinoma. Major subtypes of thyroid carcinoma and their relative frequencies are as follows: • Papillary carcinoma - most common • Follicular carcinoma • Medullary carcinoma • Anaplastic carcinoma - least common Thyroid carcinomas are derived from the thyroid follicular epithelium, except medullary 
carcinoma which is derived from parafollicular C cells.

questions.question:
Question 11: A patient with a long-standing history of thyroglossal cyst develops a neck swelling. The 
biopsy of the lesion is given below. What is the probable diagnosis? 1142 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows psammoma bodies, which are seen in papillary carcinoma of the 
thyroid. This type of carcinoma is associated with a history of long-standing unresected 
thyroglossal cyst. 1154 
Sold by @itachibot Psammoma bodies are concentrically calcified structures often present within the cores of papillae 
in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. These structures are almost never found in follicular and 
medullary carcinomas. They arise from: • Infarction and dystrophic calcification of papillae tips • Calcification of intra-lymphatic tumor thrombi. Psammoma bodies are seen in: • Papillary carcinoma (thyroid, kidney, endometrium, lungs) • Prolactinoma • Meningioma • Papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary

questions.question:
Question 12: A 30-year-old woman presented with a solitary, non-tender, firm nodule on the left side of 
her neck. Thyroid function tests were within normal limits. A fine-needle biopsy revealed 
malignant cells. The tumor was excised and examined under light microscopy as shown 
below. What is the most probable diagnosis? 1143 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The presence of empty appearing nuclei, also called Orphan Annie eye nuclei as seen in the above 
image is diagnostic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Microscopic features of papillary thyroid carcinoma include: • Branching papillae with fibrovascular stalk • Covering epithelium is simple or stratified cuboidal • Orphan Annie eye nuclei - • Empty-appearing nuclei due to dispersed chromatin • They are diagnostic, regardless of papillary architecture • Psammoma bodies - concentric calcified structures • Foci of lymphatic invasion 1155 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Orphan Annie refers to a comic book character with empty appearing eyes, as shown below. 1156 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following statements regarding papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is incorrect?

options.a: It is the most common form of thyroid carcinoma
options.b: Diagnosis can be made based on nuclear features, even in the absence of typical architecture
options.c: It is associated with previous exposure to ionizing radiation

questions.explanation:
Hematogenous spread is rare in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Metastases to lymph nodes 
are more commonly associated with this condition. It is associated with previous exposure to ionizing radiation. The presence of nuclear features such 
as Orphan Annie eye nuclei (empty-appearing nuclei) are diagnostic, regardless of papillary 
architecture. 1157 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: A pathologist is studying the following FNAC from a patient's thyroid nodule. Which is the 
most common site of metastasis for this condition?
questions.explanation:
The FNAC image is suggestive of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Among the given options, the 
most common site of metastasis is the lungs. The histological features of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid are: • Papillary architecture • Nuclear findings (enough to diagnose the condition even in the absence of papillary architecture) • Nuclear overlapping, grooving, crowding • Ground-glass appearance (Orphan Annie eye nuclei) • Dusty and pale chromatin 1158 
Sold by @itachibot • Intranuclear inclusion bodies The most common mode of spread overall is through the lymphatic route, with lymph node 
metastases being common at initial presentation.

questions.question:
Question 15: In patients with papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, which of the following genes may be 
involved?
questions.explanation:
Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is associated with gain-of-function mutations in the following 
genes: • NTRK1 (receptor tyrosine kinase) • RET (receptor tyrosine kinase) • BRAF (serine/threonine kinase)

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is the most common variant of papillary thyroid cancer?
questions.explanation:
The most common variant of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is the follicular variant. It has the following features: • Characteristic nuclear features of papillary carcinoma • Almost entirely follicular architecture • Can be either - • Encapsulated - favorable prognosis (or) • Poorly circumscribed and infiltrative - requires aggressive treatment The variants of papillary carcinoma include: Variant

ar accident Note: According to the latest WHO classification of thyroid tumors, the non-invasive encapsulated 
follicular variant of papillary thyroid carcinoma (FVPTC) has been renamed as non-invasive 
follicular thyroid neoplasm with papillary-like nuclear features (NIFTP) to better reflect the 
indolent course of this tumor. This was done to prevent potential overtreatment and reduce the 
burden to patients of a cancer diagnosis.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following patients is likely to have the best prognosis?

options.a: A 30-year-old man with papillary carcinoma thyroid
options.b: A 45-year-old woman with follicular carcinoma thyroid
options.c: A 78-year-old man with anaplastic carcinoma thyroid
options.d: A young man with MEN- II syndrome having medullary carcinoma thyroid

questions.explanation:
Papillary thyroid cancers have the best prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate seen in more than 
95% of the patients. The prognosis of papillary thyroid cancers is dependent on several factors, including age (being 
less favorable among patients older than 40 years), the presence of extrathyroidal extension, and 
presence of distant metastases. The thyroid cancer with the worst prognosis is anaplastic carcinoma.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 56-year-old woman coming from a hilly area presents with a hard swelling in the neck 
which moves up with deglutition and does not move with protrusion of the tongue. The 
biopsy of the frozen section is given below. What is your diagnosis? 1145 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with the given histopathological image showing uniform sheets 
of cells with capsular invasion by tumor cells is suggestive of follicular carcinoma thyroid. The following images show follicular carcinoma of the thyroid. 1160 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: In follicular adenoma, there is no capsular invasion. Option C: Anaplastic carcinoma is associated with rapidly progressive swelling with obstructive 
features and undifferentiated cells on histopathology. Option D: In medullary carcinoma, amyloid stroma is seen on histopathology.

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following mutations may be found in patients with follicular carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
RAS mutations are associated with follicular carcinoma. It is also associated with acquired mutations in the PIK3CA gene (PI3K/AKT arm of the receptor 
tyrosine kinase signaling pathway) and the PAX8-PPARG fusion gene. 1161 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following is not a proto-oncogene implicated in carcinoma of thyroid?
questions.explanation:
p53 is is a tumor-suppressor gene and not an oncogene. The following are the proto-oncogenes implicated in carcinoma of the thyroid. Proto-oncog 
ene Tumor RAS

ancerAnaplastic carcinoma

questions.question:
Question 21: A middle-aged woman presents with thyroid swelling. The histology of the swelling is as 
shown below. Investigations reveal elevated calcitonin levels. Which of the following is 
associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and histological appearance showing amyloid stroma are suggestive of 
medullary carcinoma of the thyroid. This condition can occur in the setting of MEN2A (Sipple 
syndrome) or MEN2B. 1162 
Sold by @itachibot Medullary carcinomas of the thyroid are neuroendocrine neoplasms derived from the 
parafollicular cells or C cells of the thyroid. They may be: • Sporadic (70%) • Familial or associated with MEN2 syndromes (30%) - • More aggressive and metastasize more frequently than sporadic • Usually bilateral and multicentric Both forms can be associated with RET mutations. These tumors may present with: • Mass in the neck • Dysphagia • Hoarseness • Diarrhea due to the secretion of VIP • Cushing's syndrome due to ACTH secretion Histopathology shows polygonal to spindle-shaped cells, which may form nests, trabeculae, and 
even follicles. Acellular amyloid deposits derived from calcitonin polypeptides are present in the 
stroma. These lesions secrete calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen. 1163 
Sold by @itachibot The Adrenals
